frame.name: Word_relations
frame.definition:
<def-root>One linguistic unit, <fen>Sign_1</fen>, has a relation to another linguistic unit, <fen>Sign_2</fen>. This relation may be semantic, phonological, orthographic, or distributional in nature. The parameter along which the two signs are set in relation to each other is incorporated in the meaning of the target words in this frame. When the relation is symmetrical, the two linguistic units can be expressed jointly, <fen>Signs</fen>. Otherwise they have to be expressed disjointly. Ordinarily it is assumed that one linguistic unit has exactly one meaning but in cases where this is not so, a set of <fen>Circumstances</fen> may be specified that helps pick out the relevant sense.
<ex> <fex name="Signs">Happy and sad</fex> are <t>antonyms</t>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Circumstances">In one sense</fex>, <fex name="Sign_1">dog</fex> is a <t>hyponym</t> of <fex name="Sign_2">itself</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Sign_1
FE.definition: <def-root>FN: a linguistic unit that carries semantic, phonological or syntactic information. <ex> In one sense, <fex name="Sign_1">dog</fex> is a <t>hyponym</t> of itself.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Sign_2
FE.definition:
<def-root>FN: a linguistic unit
<ex>In one sense, dog is a <t>hyponym</t> of <fex name="Sign_2">itself</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Signs
FE.definition: <def-root>FN: Linguistic units <ex> <fex name="Signs">Happy and sad</fex> are <t>antonyms</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Circumstances</fen> are conditions under which the relationship holds between <fen>Sign_1</fen> and <fen>Sign_2</fen>.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: synonym.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a word or phrase that means the same as another word or phrase in the same language, e.g. shut and close.

lexUnit.name: antonym.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a word opposite in meaning to another

lexUnit.name: hyponym.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: denoting a subtype of what another lexical unit denotes

lexUnit.name: hypernym.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a linguistic expression denoting a superordinate concept

lexUnit.name: synonymous.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of a word or phrase) having the same meaning as another word or phrase in the same language.

lexUnit.name: meronym.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a linguistic expression that names a part of a larger whole

lexUnit.name: holonym.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a linguistic expressions that names the whole of which a given linguistic expression is a part

lexUnit.name: homophone.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: each of two or more words having the same pronunciation but different meanings, origins, or spelling (e.g. new and knew).

lexUnit.name: homograph.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: each of two or more words spelled the same but having different meanings and origins.

lexUnit.name: collocate.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a linguistic expression that fequently co-occurs with another linguistic expression

lexUnit.name: collocate.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to frequently co-occur with another linguistic expression

lexUnit.name: homonym.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: each of two or more words having the same spelling and pronunciation but different meanings and origins (e.g. pole #1 and pole #2 ).

lexUnit.name: homophonous.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of a word or words) having the same pronunciation as another but different meaning, origin, or spelling
